title.narrative: UNECE Promoting Innovation in Eastern Europe
UNECE Utveckling av innovationssystem i Östeuropa

description.narrative: Overall objective: Innovation policy institutions have improved competencies in designing, running, reforming and monitoring effective innovation policies and institutions, that make measurable contributions towards long-term economic development, integration within EaP and the EU and sustainable development. Specific objective 1: Increase common understanding among innovation policy makers on what makes policies effective, what is needed to implement them, and what is needed to ensure continuous improvement in their countries and the EaP region as a whole. Specific objective 2: Help EaP countries initiate, guide or substantially improve specific policies, instruments, institutions, reforms and processes through targeted ECE support.

The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) has applied for funding from Sida of 2, 215, 026 USD to carry out the project "Promoting innovation policy capacities in Eastern Europe and the Caucasus" during the period 2018-2022. The intervention aims at improving competencies among innovation policy institutions in designing, running, reforming and monitoring effective innovation policies and institutions. This will be done through (1) the development and regional implementation of an innovation policy index, (2) the cunduct of Innovation Performance Reviews for Sustainable Development in Georgia, Moldova and Armenia and (3) targeted capacity building in Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and on a regional level.

United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) har inkommit med en ansökan till Sida om 2, 215, 026 USD för genomförandet av projektet "Promoting innovation policy capacities in Eastern Europe and the Caucasus" under perioden 2018-2022. Insatsen syftar till stärkt kapacitet hos policyinstitut och beslutsfattare för att skapa, implementera, reformera och underhålla ett funktionellt regelverk och effektiva institutioner för innovation. Detta görs genom (1) utveckling och implementering av ett index för att mäta innovationspolicy, (2) genomförande av studier av nationella innovationssystem (Innovation Performance Reviews for Sustainable Development) i Georgien, Moldavien och Armenien, samt (3) riktade kapacitetsutvecklingsinsatser i Vitryssland, Georgien, Moldavien samt på regional nivå.

title.narrative: Agreement between Sweden and UNECE reg. contribution no. 12333

description.narrative: From informal reports from UNECE, the main achievements in 2019 made possible by Sida funding are the following. 1. Progress on Innovation policy outlook (IPO). UNECE has completed a first stage of an IPO for Eastern Europe. The IPO is an analysis of the innovation reform climate in Eastern Europe. It aims to complement global innovation indices such as the Global Innovation Index of the EU Innovation Scoreboard. It evaluates and compares the scope and quality of the political measures countries in the Eastern Partnership have taken in the area of Innovation, as well as the institutions and processes they have in place for to promote innovation as a leading means of achieving its sustainable development goals. It is based on the experience and knowledge gathered by UNECE through its Innovation for Sustainable Development Reviews at national level (conducted in Belarus twice, in Armenia, in Ukraine, and in Georgia). Work during 2019 included the development of a methodology and process for the IPO, partly by engaging countries both politically and technically. UNECE has during 2019 developed a methodology, engaging all countries despite tensions and political turbulence, and completed the information collection. The IPO is predicted to be finalized for publication in the fall of 2020. 2. National capacity development for Belarus With Sida funds, ECE has launched a new process to help countries that have been the subject of I4SD (Innovations for Sustainable Development) reviews to implement reforms in line with its results and recommendations. Based on a Belarus review, launched in 2017, ECE and the State Committee for Science and Technology developed a program to launch a new venture capital structure for innovative projects involving both state and private capital. This means a significant rethinking of the structures and measures already in place in that country. Despite initial challenges, UNECE has now, after three events, managed to engage a local working group involving both public administration, development banks, and investors, to develop and discuss the details of this plan. The plan will be presented in May, 2020.
